docs.title: 1. 🎯 Purpose
docs.text: Global State Sharing — enables data sharing across components without prop drilling.

docs.title: 🧠 Key Uses
docs.text:
• Avoids deeply nested prop passing
  • Centralizes global or shared state
  • Enables cross-component communication

💡 Ideal for themes, authentication, language, and app-wide state.

docs.title: Create Context
docs.text: const MyContext = React.createContext(defaultValue);

docs.title: Provide Context
docs.text:
<MyContext.Provider value={currentValue}>
  {/* Child components */}
</MyContext.Provider>

const value = useContext(MyContext);

docs.title: 1️⃣ Create Context
docs.text: const ThemeContext = React.createContext();

docs.title: 2️⃣ Provide Value
docs.text:
function App() {
  const [theme, setTheme] = useState('light');

  return (
    <ThemeContext.Provider value={{ theme, setTheme }}>
      <Header />
      <Content />
    </ThemeContext.Provider>
  );
}

docs.title: 3️⃣ Consume Value
docs.text:
function Header() {
  const { theme, setTheme } = useContext(ThemeContext);

  return (
    <header className={theme}>
      <button onClick={() => setTheme('dark')}>Toggle Theme</button>
    </header>
  );
}

docs.text:
const ThemeContext = React.createContext();
// Share light/dark mode across app

docs.title: 🔐 User Authentication
docs.text:
const AuthContext = React.createContext();
// Share user data, login, and logout

docs.title: 🌍 Language / Locale

docs.title: 🧱 Multiple Contexts
docs.text:
function App() {
  return (
    <ThemeContext.Provider value={theme}>
      <AuthContext.Provider value={auth}>
        <UserContext.Provider value={user}>
          <Component />
        </UserContext.Provider>
      </AuthContext.Provider>
    </ThemeContext.Provider>
  );
}

function Component() {
  const theme = useContext(ThemeContext);
  const auth = useContext(AuthContext);
  const user = useContext(UserContext);
}

💡 Combine multiple contexts when different data domains are needed.

docs.title: ⚙️ Custom Provider Component
docs.text:
function ThemeProvider({ children }) {
  const [theme, setTheme] = useState('light');

  const value = {
    theme,
    toggleTheme: () =>
      setTheme((prev) => (prev === 'light' ? 'dark' : 'light')),
  };

  return (
    <ThemeContext.Provider value={value}>{children}</ThemeContext.Provider>
  );
}

docs.title: 🧭 Default Values
docs.text:
const ThemeContext = React.createContext({
  theme: 'light',
  toggleTheme: () => {},
});
// Used if no Provider exists in component tree

docs.title: 🧠 Re-render Optimization
docs.text:
// ❌ Causes re-renders: new object every render
<ThemeContext.Provider value={{ theme, setTheme }}>

// ✅ Memoized value object
const themeValue = useMemo(() => ({ theme, setTheme }), [theme]);

<ThemeContext.Provider value={themeValue}>

docs.title: 🧩 Separate Contexts for Different Concerns
docs.text:
// ❌ One giant context
const AppContext = React.createContext();

// ✅ Split logically
const ThemeContext = React.createContext();
const UserContext = React.createContext();
const SettingsContext = React.createContext();

✅ Smaller, focused contexts = fewer re-renders and better scalability.

docs.title: ❗ Missing Provider
docs.text:
// ❌ No Provider → uses defaultValue (often undefined)
const value = useContext(ThemeContext);

// ✅ Wrap with Provider
<ThemeContext.Provider value={actualValue}>
  <Component />
</ThemeContext.Provider>;

docs.title: 🔁 Unnecessary Re-renders
docs.text:
// ❌ New object every render
<Context.Provider value={{ data, setData }}>

// ✅ Memoize value
const contextValue = useMemo(() => ({ data, setData }), [data]);

docs.title: 🏗️ Over-nesting Providers
docs.text:
// ❌ Too many nested Providers
<AProvider><BProvider><CProvider>...

// ✅ Combine or extract into a custom hook/provider

docs.title: 8. 💡 Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Do’s

  1. Create contexts close to where they’re used
  2. Use meaningful names (e.g., UserContext, not Context1)
  3. Provide default values for better testing and safety
  4. Split logically — use multiple small contexts
  5. Memoize context values to prevent extra re-renders

❌ Don’ts

  • Avoid a “mega context” for everything
  • Don’t skip wrapping consumers with providers
  • Don’t create new value objects inline each render

docs.title: 9. 🧩 Custom Hook Pattern
docs.text:
Encapsulate context logic inside a custom hook for reusability and safety.

function useTheme() {
  const context = useContext(ThemeContext);
  if (!context) {
    throw new Error('useTheme must be used within a ThemeProvider');
  }
  return context;
}

💡 Simplifies imports and ensures context is properly used.

docs.title: 10. 🎯 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• 🧭 Solves prop drilling — share state globally
  • ⚙️ Provider / Consumer pattern — wrap and consume
  • 🚀 Optimize performance — memoize context values
  • 🧩 Use multiple contexts — avoid overloading one
  • 🔧 Provide defaults — prevent runtime errors

✅ Summary: useContext is the go-to React Hook for sharing global or cross-component state efficiently. When used with memoization, custom hooks, and context separation, it leads to clean, scalable, and high-performance React architectures.

docs.title: 1. 🎯 Purpose
docs.text:
Manages side effects in React components such as:

  • 🌐 Data fetching
  • 🔔 Subscriptions
  • ⏱️ Timers
  • 🧩 DOM manipulation
  • 🔧 API calls

💡 Definition: A side effect is any operation that affects something outside the component’s render (like network requests, subscriptions, or DOM changes).

docs.title: 2. 📝 Syntax
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  // Effect logic

  return () => {
    // Cleanup logic
  };
}, [dependencies]);
  • First argument → Effect callback
  • Return function → Cleanup (optional)
  • Dependency array → Controls execution frequency

docs.title: ⚙️ No Dependency Array
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  // Runs after EVERY render
});

⚠️ Re-runs on every state or prop change — use sparingly.

docs.title: 🧱 Empty Array
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  // Runs ONCE after initial render
  // Equivalent to componentDidMount
}, []);

docs.title: 🎯 With Dependencies
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  // Runs when dep1 or dep2 changes
  // Equivalent to componentDidUpdate
}, [dep1, dep2]);

✅ Add all variables used inside the effect to ensure predictable updates.

docs.title: 🖱️ Event Listeners
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  const handleClick = () => console.log('clicked');
  document.addEventListener('click', handleClick);

  return () => document.removeEventListener('click', handleClick);
}, []);

docs.title: 🔄 Subscriptions
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  const subscription = API.subscribe((data) => setData(data));

  return () => subscription.unsubscribe();
}, []);

docs.title: ⏰ Timers
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  const timer = setInterval(() => console.log('tick'), 1000);

  return () => clearInterval(timer);
}, []);

docs.title: ❗ Missing Dependencies
docs.text:
// ❌ Missing count dependency
useEffect(() => {
  document.title = `Count: ${count}`;
}, []);

// ✅ Include all used values
useEffect(() => {
  document.title = `Count: ${count}`;
}, [count]);

docs.title: 🔁 Infinite Loops
docs.text:
// ❌ Infinite re-renders
useEffect(() => {
  setState(state + 1); // triggers re-render
}); // No dependency array

// ✅ Fixed with proper dependencies
useEffect(() => {
  // Logic that doesn’t trigger re-render
}, [someDependency]);

docs.title: 🧠 Stale Closures
docs.text:
// ❌ Uses stale state value
useEffect(() => {
  const id = setInterval(() => {
    console.log(count); // Always initial value
  }, 1000);
  return () => clearInterval(id);
}, []);

// ✅ Correct: use functional updates or deps
useEffect(() => {
  const id = setInterval(() => {
    setCount((prev) => prev + 1);
  }, 1000);
  return () => clearInterval(id);
}, []);

docs.title: ⚙️ Conditional Effects
docs.text:
useEffect(() => {
  if (shouldFetch) {
    fetchData();
  }
}, [shouldFetch]); // Runs only when shouldFetch changes

docs.title: 🧩 Multiple Effects
docs.text:
// Separate unrelated logic
useEffect(() => {
  // API call
}, [userId]);

useEffect(() => {
  // DOM update
}, [isVisible]);

docs.title: ⏳ Skip Initial Run
docs.text:
const isFirstRender = useRef(true);

useEffect(() => {
  if (isFirstRender.current) {
    isFirstRender.current = false;
    return;
  }
  // Effect logic for updates only
}, [dependency]);

💡 Helpful when you want logic to run only after the first render.

docs.title: 7. 🔄 Lifecycle Equivalents
docs.text: Class Lifecycle Hook Equivalent componentDidMount useEffect(() => {}, []) componentDidUpdate useEffect(() => {}, [deps]) componentWillUnmount useEffect(() => return cleanup, [])

docs.title: 8. 💡 Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Do’s

  • Declare dependencies honestly — trust ESLint
  • Separate concerns with multiple effects
  • Always cleanup listeners, timers, and subscriptions
  • Use empty array only for mount/unmount behavior
  • Extract repeated logic into custom hooks

❌ Don’ts

  • Don’t skip dependencies to “fix” warnings
  • Don’t mix unrelated logic inside one effect
  • Don’t cause state updates without dependency awareness

docs.title: 9. 🎯 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Dependency array → Controls when the effect runs
  • Cleanup function → Prevents memory leaks
  • Multiple effects → Improve maintainability
  • Include all dependencies → Avoid stale data
  • Empty array → componentDidMount + cleanup behavior

✅ Summary: useEffect is React’s way of synchronizing your component with external systems or side effects. Proper use of dependencies and cleanups ensures predictable, memory-safe, and performant components.

docs.title: useLayoutEffect
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect fires synchronously after DOM updates but before the browser paints the screen. It allows you to read layout, measure DOM elements, and block the browser from painting until your logic runs.

It behaves like useEffect but with timing differences.

docs.title: 1. 📝 Syntax
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  // run after DOM updates, before paint
  return () => {
    // cleanup
  };
}, [dependencies]);

docs.title: 2. 🎯 When to Use
docs.text:
Use useLayoutEffect when you need:

  1. DOM measurements

  2. width, height, bounding boxes

  3. Synchronous layout reads + updates

  4. measuring layout before the browser paints

  5. Prevent visual flicker

  6. updating styles before paint

  7. Mutating DOM elements

  8. scroll position
  9. focus
  10. manually applying CSS updates

docs.title: useEffect
docs.text:
• Runs after paint
  • Does not block the browser
  • Best for async logic, subscriptions, API calls

docs.title: useLayoutEffect
docs.text:
• Runs before paint
  • Blocks painting
  • Perfect for layout-sensitive logic

Timeline

Render → DOM Updated → useLayoutEffect → Browser Paint → useEffect

docs.title: 4. 📏 DOM Measurement Example
docs.text:
function Box() {
  const boxRef = useRef(null);
  const [width, setWidth] = useState(0);

  useLayoutEffect(() => {
    const rect = boxRef.current.getBoundingClientRect();
    setWidth(rect.width);
  }, []);

  return (
    <>
      <div ref={boxRef} className="box">
        Box
      </div>
      <p>Width: {width}</p>
    </>
  );
}

Here, using useEffect would cause a visible flash because the width would update after paint.

docs.title: 5. 🎛️ Synchronous Mutations Example
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  elementRef.current.style.transform = 'translateX(0)';
});
  • Ensures styling updates are applied before the browser paints
  • Prevents flickering or jumpy layout

docs.title: 6. 🧭 Scroll Position Adjustments
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  containerRef.current.scrollTop = 0;
});

Ensures scroll adjustment happens before anything is visible.

docs.title: ❌ 1. Avoid heavy work
docs.text: useLayoutEffect blocks paint — heavy logic = jank.

docs.title: ❌ 2. Do not use for API calls
docs.text: Use useEffect for async side effects.

docs.title: ❌ 3. Do not mutate layout inside render functions
docs.text: Use useLayoutEffect instead.

docs.title: ⚠️ 4. Cleanup also runs before paint
docs.text: Useful for restoring previous DOM styles.

docs.title: 8. 🚨 Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. ❌ Using useLayoutEffect for things that do not depend on layout
  2. ❌ Performing expensive operations → leads to blocking UI
  3. ⚠️ Using it everywhere instead of only layout-specific places
  4. ❌ Misunderstanding that it runs synchronously

docs.title: 9. 🚀 Performance Tips
docs.text:
• Prefer useEffect unless layout measurement is required
  • Move heavy calculations outside the effect
  • Batch DOM reads separately from DOM writes
  • Avoid re-running useLayoutEffect unnecessarily (define correct deps)

docs.title: 10. 💡 When NOT to Use useLayoutEffect
docs.text:
Avoid it when:

  • Doing API calls
  • Registering event listeners
  • Logging
  • Running async logic
  • Updating state unrelated to layout

These should use useEffect.

docs.title: 1. Auto-Focusing Without Flicker
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  inputRef.current.focus();
}, []);

docs.title: 2. Measuring Element Size Before Paint
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  const { height } = elRef.current.getBoundingClientRect();
  setHeight(height);
});

docs.title: 3. Preventing Layout Shift
docs.text:
useLayoutEffect(() => {
  if (isOpen) {
    modalRef.current.style.opacity = 1;
  }
});

docs.title: 12. 💡 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• useLayoutEffect runs before paint
  • Use it for:
  • DOM measurement
  • synchronous DOM mutations
  • avoiding flickers

  • correcting layout before display

  • Avoid heavy logic — it blocks rendering

  • Use useEffect for async/non-layout work

docs.title: useMemo
docs.text: useMemo is a React Hook that memoizes a computed value and returns a cached result. It helps avoid expensive recalculations on every render.

docs.title: 1. 📝 Syntax & Basics
docs.text:
const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => computeValue(a, b), [a, b]);
  • Returns → a memoized result
  • Only re-runs the function when dependencies change
  • Helps optimize expensive calculations or object references

docs.title: 2. 🎯 When to Use
docs.text:
Use useMemo for:

  1. Expensive calculations
  2. Derived data from state/props
  3. Avoiding re-creation of objects/arrays causing re-renders
  4. Stabilizing dependencies for useEffect, useCallback, memoized components

💡 Do NOT use it for micro-optimizations. Use only when a calculation is actually expensive.

docs.title: 3. 📊 Basic Example
docs.text:
const doubled = useMemo(() => {
  return count * 2;
}, [count]);
  • Recomputes only when count changes
  • Otherwise returns cached result

docs.title: 4. 🧮 Expensive Computation Example
docs.text:
const expensiveResult = useMemo(() => {
  return heavyCalculation(data);
}, [data]);

Without useMemo, heavyCalculation() would run every render, causing performance issues.

docs.title: 5. 🏗️ Stabilizing Object/Array References
docs.text: React compares object references, not values. Without useMemo, objects recreate each render.

docs.title: Without useMemo (Bad)
docs.text: const filters = { sort: 'asc' }; // new reference every render

docs.title: With useMemo (Good)
docs.text:
const filters = useMemo(() => ({ sort: 'asc' }), []);

This prevents unnecessary re-renders in child components or effects.

docs.title: 6. 🎛️ Memoizing Functions vs useCallback
docs.text:
useMemo memoizes values useCallback memoizes functions

const memoizedValue = useMemo(() => compute(), []);
const memoizedFn = useCallback(() => compute(), []);

Internally, this is equivalent:

useCallback(fn, deps) === useMemo(() => fn, deps)

docs.title: 1. Filtering or Sorting Data
docs.text:
const filtered = useMemo(() => {
  return items.filter((item) => item.active);
}, [items]);

docs.title: 2. Avoiding Re-renders in Child Components
docs.text:
const user = useMemo(() => ({ name }), [name]);

<Child user={user} />;

docs.title: 3. Creating Stable Styles
docs.text:
const styles = useMemo(
  () => ({
    backgroundColor: isDark ? 'black' : 'white',
  }),
  [isDark]
);

docs.title: 4. Memoizing Derived State
docs.text:
const totalPrice = useMemo(() => {
  return cart.reduce((sum, item) => sum + item.price, 0);
}, [cart]);

docs.title: ❌ 1. Don’t use for every value
docs.text: Use only when computation is expensive or reference stability matters.

docs.title: ⏳ 2. Dependency array correctness is crucial
docs.text: Wrong deps → stale or incorrect values.

docs.title: ❌ 3. Do not mutate memoized values
docs.text: Returned memoized object should be treated as immutable.

docs.title: ⚠️ 4. Memoization has a cost
docs.text: React stores cached values → unnecessary usage may worsen performance.

docs.title: 9. 🚨 Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. ❌ Using useMemo when useState or inline values are enough
  2. ⚠️ Forgetting dependency values → stale results
  3. ❌ Returning mutable object and modifying it
  4. ⚠️ Using it to "fix" re-renders instead of fixing component structure
  5. ❌ Wrapping everything in useMemo → over-optimization

docs.title: 10. 🚀 Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use for heavy computations
  • Use to stabilize objects/arrays passed to children
  • Use when a value affects useEffect dependencies
  • Keep dependency arrays accurate
  • Avoid overuse — measure performance first

docs.title: 1. Memoizing an Expensive Mapper
docs.text:
const processedList = useMemo(() => {
  return list.map((item) => slowTransform(item));
}, [list]);

docs.title: 2. Stable Object for API Params
docs.text:
const params = useMemo(
  () => ({
    page,
    sort,
  }),
  [page, sort]
);

docs.title: 3. Calculating Derived State
docs.text:
const completedCount = useMemo(() => {
  return tasks.filter((t) => t.done).length;
}, [tasks]);

docs.title: 12. 💡 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• useMemo caches values to avoid unnecessary recalculation
  • Recomputes only when dependencies change
  • Best for:
  • expensive logic
  • derived values
  • preventing unnecessary renders

  • stabilizing object/array references

  • Don’t overuse it — only when there's a real performance need

docs.title: useReducer
docs.text: useReducer is a React Hook for managing complex state logic and state that depends on previous values. It is an alternative to useState when you have multiple related state variables or complicated state updates.

docs.title: 1. 📝 Syntax & Basics
docs.text:
const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialState, init);
  • Returns → [currentState, dispatchFunction]
  • reducer → function (state, action) => newState
  • dispatch → function to send an action to the reducer
  • initialState → initial value of the state
  • init (optional) → function to lazily initialize state

docs.title: 2. 🔧 Reducer Function
docs.text:
The reducer is a pure function: given the same inputs, it always returns the same output.

function reducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case 'increment':
      return { count: state.count + 1 };
    case 'decrement':
      return { count: state.count - 1 };
    default:
      return state;
  }
}

docs.title: 3. ⚡ Dispatching Actions
docs.text:
const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, { count: 0 });

<button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: 'increment' })}>+</button>
<button onClick={() => dispatch({ type: 'decrement' })}>-</button>

<p>Count: {state.count}</p>
  • dispatch({ type: '...' }) triggers the reducer
  • action can also include a payload for dynamic data
dispatch({ type: 'set', payload: 10 });

docs.text:
const initialState = 0;
function reducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case 'increment':
      return state + 1;
    case 'decrement':
      return state - 1;
    default:
      return state;
  }
}

docs.title: 👤 Objects
docs.text:
const initialState = { count: 0, name: '' };

function reducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case 'increment':
      return { ...state, count: state.count + 1 };
    case 'setName':
      return { ...state, name: action.payload };
    default:
      return state;
  }
}

docs.text:
const initialState = [];

function reducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case 'add':
      return [...state, action.payload];
    case 'remove':
      return state.filter((item) => item.id !== action.payload.id);
    default:
      return state;

}

docs.title: ❌ Reducer Must Be Pure
docs.text:
• No side effects inside the reducer
  • Do not call APIs or mutate variables outside

docs.title: ❌ Never Mutate State
docs.text:
// ❌ WRONG
state.count += 1;

// ✅ CORRECT
return { ...state, count: state.count + 1 };

docs.title: ⏳ Dispatch Is Asynchronous
docs.text:
• Multiple dispatches may be batched
  • State updates are not immediate

docs.title: Lazy Initialization
docs.text:
const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialArg, initFunction);

function initFunction(initialValue) {
  return { count: initialValue };
}
  • Useful for expensive initializations
  • Runs once on mount

docs.title: Action Payloads
docs.text:
dispatch({ type: 'setCount', payload: 10 });
  • Reduces need for multiple action types
  • Can store dynamic data

docs.title: Combined State Management
docs.text:
const initialState = {
  loading: false,
  error: null,
  data: [],
};

function reducer(state, action) {
  switch (action.type) {
    case 'fetchStart':
      return { ...state, loading: true, error: null };
    case 'fetchSuccess':
      return { ...state, loading: false, data: action.payload };
    case 'fetchError':
      return { ...state, loading: false, error: action.payload };

const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, { isOpen: false });

function reducer(state, action) {

const initialForm = { email: '', password: '' };

function formReducer(state, action) {

const [form, dispatch] = useReducer(formReducer, initialForm);

dispatch({ field: 'email', value: 'user@example.com' });

docs.title: useRef - Complete Notes
docs.text: useRef is a React Hook used to store mutable values that persist across renders without causing re-renders. It can also hold references to DOM elements.

docs.title: 1. 📝 Syntax & Basics
docs.text:
const ref = useRef(initialValue);
  • Returns → an object: { current: initialValue }
  • Updating ref.current does not trigger re-render
  • Value persists across re-renders

docs.title: 2. 🎯 Common Uses
docs.text:
1. Accessing DOM elements
  2. Storing mutable values that shouldn’t trigger re-renders
  3. Storing previous values
  4. Storing timers, intervals, event handlers
  5. Avoiding re-creation of objects/functions

docs.title: Basic Example
docs.text:
function App() {
  const inputRef = useRef(null);

  const focusInput = () => {
    inputRef.current.focus();
  };

  return (
    <>
      <input ref={inputRef} />
      <button onClick={focusInput}>Focus</button>
    </>
  );
}

docs.title: What happens?
docs.text:
• ref={inputRef} assigns DOM node to inputRef.current
  • No re-render when accessing or modifying ref.current

docs.title: 4. 🔄 Mutable Values (No Re-render)
docs.text:
const countRef = useRef(0);

function increment() {
  countRef.current += 1;
}
  • Changing countRef.current → does not update UI
  • Useful for storing values that don’t belong in UI state

docs.title: 5. 🧠 Storing Previous Values
docs.text:
const previousValue = useRef();

useEffect(() => {
  previousValue.current = value;
}, [value]);
  • previousValue.current holds value from previous render
  • Useful for comparisons/effects

docs.title: 6. ⏳ Timer / Interval References
docs.text:
const timerRef = useRef(null);

function start() {
  timerRef.current = setInterval(() => {
    console.log('running...');
  }, 1000);
}

function stop() {
  clearInterval(timerRef.current);
}
  • Store timer IDs to clean them later
  • Prevents stale closures

docs.title: 7. ⚡ Avoiding Re-Creation (Stable References)
docs.text:
useRef gives a stable object that never changes between renders.

const stableObject = useRef({ a: 1 });
  • Useful for storing values tied to component lifetime
  • Similar to instance variables in OOP components

docs.title: ❌ 1. Changing ref.current does NOT cause re-render
docs.text: Use useState if UI must update.

docs.title: ❌ 2. Refs are mutable — but React does not track changes
docs.text: Do not rely on refs to trigger updates.

docs.title: ⏳ 3. Refs persist across the entire component lifetime
docs.text: They are not reset unless component unmounts.

docs.title: ⚠️ 4. Avoid using refs for "derived state"
docs.text: If UI depends on a value, use useState instead.

docs.title: 9. 🚨 Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. ❌ Using ref instead of state to update UI
  2. ⚠️ Mutating large objects in refs leading to unpredictable behavior
  3. ❌ Using ref inside render logic → value may be outdated
  4. ⚠️ Forgetting to clear timers stored in refs

docs.title: 10. 🚀 Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use useRef for non-UI values
  • Use for storing:
  • timers
  • previous values
  • DOM nodes
  • large mutable objects

  • callback references

  • Prefer useState when value must trigger UI update

  • Use useCallback + useRef for stable handlers

docs.title: 🔁 1. Tracking Render Counts
docs.text:
const renderCount = useRef(0);

useEffect(() => {
  renderCount.current += 1;
});

docs.title: 👀 2. Detecting Clicks Outside Element
docs.text:
const boxRef = useRef();

useEffect(() => {
  function handleClick(event) {
    if (boxRef.current && !boxRef.current.contains(event.target)) {
      console.log('Clicked outside!');
    }
  }

  document.addEventListener('mousedown', handleClick);
  return () => document.removeEventListener('mousedown', handleClick);
}, []);

docs.title: 🧵 3. Persisting Data Without Re-Renders
docs.text:
const latestValueRef = useRef(value);

useEffect(() => {
  latestValueRef.current = value;
}, [value]);

docs.title: 🧩 4. Stable Event Handler Reference (Advanced)
docs.text:
const callbackRef = useRef(onChange);

useEffect(() => {
  callbackRef.current = onChange;
});

function handleClick() {
  callbackRef.current();
}

docs.title: 12. 💡 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• Refs are for mutable, non-UI, persistent values
  • Updating ref.current does not re-render
  • Ideal for:
  • DOM access
  • timers
  • storing previous values

  • avoiding re-renders

  • Think of refs as instance variables in functional components

docs.title: 1. 📝 Syntax & Basics
docs.text:
const [state, setState] = useState(initialValue);
  • Returns → [currentValue, updaterFunction]
  • Initial render → uses initialValue
  • Subsequent renders → uses latest state

docs.title: 2. 🎯 Initial State Patterns
docs.text:
// Simple value
const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

// Lazy initializer (runs once)
const [data, setData] = useState(() => expensiveCalculation());

// Object state
const [user, setUser] = useState({ name: '', age: 0 });

// Array state
const [items, setItems] = useState([]);

docs.title: ⚙️ Direct Update
docs.text:
setCount(5);
setName('John');
setIsVisible(true);

docs.title: ⚡ Functional Update (Recommended)
docs.text:
setCount((prev) => prev + 1);
setItems((prev) => [...prev, newItem]);

💡 Use functional updates when:

  • Multiple state updates occur in sequence
  • Async operations depend on previous state
  • Batch updates are needed
  • New state depends on previous state

docs.title: 🔢 Primitives
docs.text:
// Number
const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

// String
const [text, setText] = useState('');

// Boolean
const [isOpen, setIsOpen] = useState(false);

docs.title: 👤 Objects (Immutable Updates)
docs.text:
const [user, setUser] = useState({ name: 'John', age: 30 });

// Update
setUser((prev) => ({ ...prev, age: 31 }));

// Nested object
setUser((prev) => ({
  ...prev,
  profile: { ...prev.profile, city: 'NYC' },
}));

docs.title: 🧾 Arrays (Immutable Updates)
docs.text:
const [items, setItems] = useState(['a', 'b']);

// Add
setItems((prev) => [...prev, 'c']);

// Remove
setItems((prev) => prev.filter((item) => item !== 'b'));

// Update
setItems((prev) => prev.map((item) => (item === 'a' ? 'updated' : item)));

docs.title: ❌ 1. Never Mutate State Directly
docs.text:
// ❌ WRONG
state.count = 5;
state.items.push(newItem);

// ✅ CORRECT
setCount(5);
setItems((prev) => [...prev, newItem]);

docs.title: ⏳ 2. State Updates Are Asynchronous
docs.text:
// ❌ Don't rely on immediate update
console.log(count); // old value
setCount(count + 1);
console.log(count); // still old value

// ✅ Use functional updates for consecutive changes
setCount((prev) => prev + 1);
setCount((prev) => prev + 1);

docs.title: 🧩 3. Object/Array Updates Need New References
docs.text:
// ❌ Won’t re-render (same reference)
stateObj.name = 'new';
setStateObj(stateObj);

// ✅ New reference triggers re-render
setStateObj({ ...stateObj, name: 'new' });

docs.title: ⚡ Lazy Initial State
docs.text:
// ✅ Only runs once
const [data, setData] = useState(() => {
  return expensiveComputation();
});

docs.title: 🧠 Batching Updates (React 18+)
docs.text:
// ✅ Single re-render in most cases
const handleClick = () => {
  setCount((c) => c + 1);
  setName('John');
  setActive(true);
};

docs.title: 🔁 Toggle State
docs.text:
const [isOn, setIsOn] = useState(false);
const toggle = () => setIsOn((prev) => !prev);

docs.title: 📝 Form State
docs.text:
const [form, setForm] = useState({ email: '', password: '' });

const updateField = (field, value) => {
  setForm((prev) => ({ ...prev, [field]: value }));
};

docs.title: 🧩 Multiple Related States
docs.text:
// Option 1: Separate states
const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);
const [error, setError] = useState(null);
const [data, setData] = useState(null);

// Option 2: Combined state
const [state, setState] = useState({
  loading: false,
  error: null,
  data: null,
});

docs.title: 8. 🚨 Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. ❌ Mutating state directly → No re-render
  2. ⚠️ Using stale state in callbacks → Use functional updates
  3. ⚠️ Forgetting spread operator → Lost properties
  4. 🧱 Over-nesting state → Complex updates
  5. 🌀 Too many useState calls → Consider useReducer

docs.title: 9. ✅ Best Practices
docs.text:
• Use multiple useState hooks for unrelated data
  • Group related fields in objects
  • Prefer functional updates
  • Use lazy initializers for expensive computations
  • Keep state minimal; compute derived data via useMemo

docs.title: 10. 💡 Key Takeaways
docs.text:
• State updates are async — don’t rely on immediate values
  • Always create new references for objects/arrays
  • Functional updates prevent stale state
  • Initializer functions run only once
  • Batching optimizes multiple updates

docs.title: Introduction to JSX
docs.text: JSX (JavaScript XML) is a syntax extension that lets you write UI elements using an HTML-like syntax inside JavaScript. React uses JSX to describe what the UI should look like.

docs.title: Basic Example
docs.text: const element = <h1>Hello, world!</h1>;

docs.title: Why JSX?
docs.text:
• More readable than React.createElement()
  • Keeps markup + logic together
  • Helps write declarative UI

docs.title: JSX is JavaScript
docs.text:
JSX expressions compile down to:

React.createElement(type, props, children);

JSX is optional but widely used in React apps.

docs.title: Embedding Expressions in JSX
docs.text:
You can embed JavaScript expressions inside JSX using `{}`.

## Variables

````jsx
const name = 'Alice';
<h1>Hello, {name}</h1>


## Expressions

```jsx
<p>2 + 2 = {2 + 2}</p>

## Function Calls

```jsx
<p>{getUserName()}</p>
```

## JSX is an Expression

You can store JSX in a variable or return it from a function.

```jsx
function greet(user) {
  return <h1>Hello, {user.name}</h1>;
}
```

docs.title: 🚀 React
docs.text: Short description: React is a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces, especially for single-page applications. It allows developers to create reusable UI components and efficiently update the DOM using a virtual DOM.

docs.title: 1. Introduction
docs.text:
• What is React? React is a JavaScript library for building interactive and dynamic user interfaces. It focuses on the view layer of an application and allows developers to create reusable UI components.

  • Why use it?

  • Efficient rendering using Virtual DOM.
  • Component-based architecture promotes reusability.
  • Large community and ecosystem.

  • Easy integration with other libraries and frameworks.

  • Key features & use cases:

  • Declarative: UI updates automatically when data changes.
  • Component-based: Build encapsulated components that manage their own state.
  • JSX syntax: Write HTML-like code in JavaScript.
  • Single Page Applications (SPA): Efficient routing and rendering.
  • Use cases: Web apps, dashboards, e-commerce sites, social media platforms.

docs.title: 3. Project Structure
docs.text:
• Default folder layout Typical React project structure created by create-react-app or Vite:
[project-name]/
 ├── src/           # All source code (components, styles, utils)
 ├── public/        # Static assets (index.html, images)
 ├── tests/         # Optional: unit or integration tests
 └── package.json   # Project metadata & dependencies
  • Important files and their roles
  • src/index.js / src/main.jsx: Entry point of the app.
  • src/App.js / src/App.jsx: Root component of the application.
  • public/index.html: Base HTML file where React mounts the app.

  • package.json: Contains dependencies, scripts, and project info.

  • Recommended project conventions

  • Use PascalCase for component filenames (MyComponent.jsx).
  • Keep one component per file for clarity.
  • Organize by feature or type (components, pages, utils, hooks).
  • Keep assets in a separate assets/ folder inside src.

docs.title: 4.1 Basic Syntax / Components / Views
docs.text:
• Components: Reusable pieces of UI. Can be functional or class-based (functional preferred in modern React).
  • JSX: HTML-like syntax used inside JavaScript.
// Functional Component Example
function App() {
  return <h1>Hello, World!</h1>;
}

export default App;
  • Rendering: React DOM renders components to the actual DOM:
import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import App from './App';

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(<App />);

docs.title: 4.2 Routing / Navigation
docs.text:
• React uses React Router for client-side routing.
  • Define routes and corresponding components:
import { BrowserRouter as Router, Routes, Route } from 'react-router-dom';
import Home from './Home';
import About from './About';

function App() {
  return (
    <Router>
      <Routes>
        <Route path="/" element={<Home />} />
        <Route path="/about" element={<About />} />
      </Routes>
    </Router>
  );
}

docs.title: 4.3 State / Data Management
docs.text:
• Local state: Managed within a component using useState:
import { useState } from 'react';

function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
  return <button onClick={() => setCount(count + 1)}>Count: {count}</button>;
}
  • Global state / context: Use Context API or external stores like Redux or Zustand for shared state.
  • Recommended pattern: Keep state as local as possible, lift state up only when necessary.

docs.title: 4.4 Lifecycle / Hooks / Events
docs.text:
• Lifecycle in functional components: Managed with hooks like useEffect, useLayoutEffect.
import { useEffect } from 'react';

function Example() {
  useEffect(() => {
    console.log('Component mounted');
    return () => console.log('Component unmounted');
  }, []); // Empty dependency array = runs once
}
  • Events: Attach events using JSX syntax:
<button onClick={() => alert('Clicked!')}>Click Me</button>

docs.title: 5.1 Performance Optimization
docs.text:
• Memoization: Use React.memo for components and useMemo / useCallback for functions or values to avoid unnecessary re-renders.
import React, { useMemo } from 'react';

const ExpensiveComponent = ({ data }) => {
  const computedValue = useMemo(() => heavyComputation(data), [data]);
  return <div>{computedValue}</div>;
};
  • Code splitting / Lazy loading: Load components only when needed using React.lazy and Suspense.
import React, { Suspense } from 'react';
const LazyComponent = React.lazy(() => import('./LazyComponent'));

function App() {
  return (
    <Suspense fallback={<div>Loading...</div>}>
      <LazyComponent />
    </Suspense>
  );
}

docs.title: 5.2 Error Handling / Debugging
docs.text:
• Error Boundaries: Catch runtime errors in components.
class ErrorBoundary extends React.Component {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props);
    this.state = { hasError: false };
  }

  static getDerivedStateFromError(error) {
    return { hasError: true };
  }

  render() {
    if (this.state.hasError) {
      return <h1>Something went wrong.</h1>;
    }
    return this.props.children;
  }
}
  • Debugging: Use React DevTools to inspect components, state, and props.
  • Console logging and custom hooks for debugging complex state flows.

docs.title: 5.3 Testing Strategies
docs.text:
• Unit testing: Test individual components using Jest + React Testing Library.
  • Integration testing: Test interaction between components.
  • End-to-end (E2E) testing: Use tools like Cypress to simulate user behavior.
import { render, screen } from '@testing-library/react';
import App from './App';

test('renders Hello, World!', () => {
  render(<App />);
  expect(screen.getByText(/Hello, World!/i)).toBeInTheDocument();
});

docs.title: 5.4 Middleware / Plugins / Extensions
docs.text:
• State management libraries: Redux, Zustand, Recoil.
  • Form handling: Formik, React Hook Form.
  • Styling: TailwindCSS, styled-components, Emotion.
  • Routing: React Router, Next.js (for SSR).
  • API / HTTP: Axios, React Query, SWR for data fetching.

docs.title: 6. Common Commands / Scripts
docs.text:
Action Command Start project (dev server) npm start Build project (production) npm run build Run tests npm test Lint code npm run lint Install dependencies npm install Add a package npm install <package-name> Remove a package npm uninstall <package-name> Run formatting (Prettier) npm run format Run storybook (if used) npm run storybook
  • Notes:
  • npm start typically runs the app in development mode with hot-reloading.
  • npm run build creates a production-ready build/ folder.
  • Linting ensures code consistency and helps catch potential errors early.
  • Testing scripts vary depending on the setup (Jest, React Testing Library, Cypress, etc.).

docs.title: 7.1 Folder Structure Conventions
docs.text:
• Keep components in a components/ directory, organized by feature.
  • Use hooks/, contexts/, utils/, and services/ folders for separation of concerns.
  • Maintain a consistent naming convention: PascalCase for components, camelCase for utility functions, and kebab-case for files.
  • Example:
src/
 ├── components/
 ├── hooks/
 ├── contexts/
 ├── services/
 ├── utils/
 └── App.jsx

docs.title: 7.2 Code Style Recommendations
docs.text:
• Prefer functional components + hooks over class components.
  • Use ESLint + Prettier for linting and formatting.
  • Keep components small and reusable — follow the single responsibility principle.
  • Write prop types or use TypeScript for type safety.

docs.title: 7.3 Versioning and Updates
docs.text:
• Use semantic versioning (semver): MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH.
  • Regularly update dependencies, but pin versions in package.json to avoid breaking changes.
  • Test thoroughly after React or library upgrades.

docs.title: 7.4 Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Avoid dangerouslySetInnerHTML unless absolutely necessary.
  • Sanitize user inputs before rendering.
  • Keep dependencies updated to patch vulnerabilities.

docs.title: 📘 React Terms & Concepts
docs.text: A concise reference to understand common React concepts — what, where, why, and how (with short code examples).

docs.title: State
docs.text:
• What: Data managed by a component that determines what renders.
  • Where: Inside components using useState.
  • Example:
const [count, setCount] = useState(0);
setCount(count + 1);

docs.title: Props
docs.text:
• What: Data passed from parent to child component.
  • Where: Used to make components reusable and dynamic.
  • Example:
<Button label="Click Me" />
function Button({ label }) { return <button>{label}</button>; }

docs.title: Lifting Up State
docs.text:
• What: Moving shared state to the nearest common parent component.
  • Where: When multiple child components need the same data.
  • Example:
// Parent holds shared state
const [value, setValue] = useState('');
<ChildInput value={value} onChange={setValue} />
<ChildDisplay value={value} />

docs.title: Controlled Input
docs.text:
• What: Input element whose value is controlled by React state.
  • Where: Used in forms for validation and state sync.
  • Example:
const [name, setName] = useState('');
<input value={name} onChange={(e) => setName(e.target.value)} />

docs.title: Uncontrolled Input
docs.text:
• What: Input managed by the DOM (not React state).
  • Where: When you only need value occasionally (e.g., on submit).
  • Example:
const inputRef = useRef();
<input ref={inputRef} />

docs.title: State Updates Are Asynchronous
docs.text:
• What: React batches state updates and applies them after rendering.
  • Why: Improves performance by avoiding multiple re-renders.
  • Example:
setCount(count + 1);
console.log(count); // old value, updates after render

docs.title: Render
docs.text:
• What: The process where React calls your component to produce JSX.
  • When: Happens after every state or prop change.

docs.title: Virtual DOM
docs.text:
• What: A lightweight in-memory tree representing the real DOM.
  • Why: Enables efficient comparison (diffing) before updating the real DOM.

docs.title: Reconciliation Process
docs.text:
• What: React’s algorithm that compares the new and old virtual DOM and updates only what changed.
  • Example:
// Only changed text will re-render
<p>{count}</p>

docs.title: Diffing
docs.text:
• What: The comparison of new vs old virtual DOM nodes.
  • Why: Determines minimal real DOM changes for better performance.

docs.title: Commit Phase
docs.text: • What: After diffing, React updates the actual DOM and runs effects.

docs.title: Functional Components
docs.text:
• What: Standard function-based React components using hooks.
  • Example:
function Greeting({ name }) {
  return <h1>Hello, {name}</h1>;
}

docs.title: Pure Components
docs.text:
• What: Components that render the same output for the same props/state.
  • Why: Improves performance by skipping re-renders.
  • Example:
export default React.memo(MyComponent);

docs.title: Key Prop
docs.text:
• What: Unique identifier for list items to help React track them.
  • Example:
{items.map(item => <li key={item.id}>{item.name}</li>)}

docs.title: Fragment
docs.text:
• What: A wrapper that groups elements without adding extra DOM nodes.
  • Example:
<>
  <Header />
  <Content />
</>

docs.title: Shallow Copy
docs.text:
• What: Copies only top-level properties (nested objects remain references).
  • Example:
const newObj = { ...oldObj };

docs.title: Deep Copy
docs.text:
• What: Copies all nested levels recursively.
  • Example:
const deepCopy = JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(oldObj));

docs.title: Shallow Comparison
docs.text:
• What: Compares references, not deep values.
  • Where: Used by React.memo and PureComponent to detect prop changes.
  • Example:
obj1 === obj2 // false even if contents are same

docs.title: Mount
docs.text:
• Component is added to the DOM.
  • Example: useEffect(() => { ... }, []);

docs.title: Update
docs.text: • Component re-renders when props or state change.

docs.title: Unmount
docs.text:
• Component is removed from DOM, cleanup runs.
  • Example:
useEffect(() => {
  return () => console.log('Cleanup on unmount');
}, []);

docs.title: useEffect
docs.text:
• What: Runs side effects like fetching data or event subscriptions.
  • Example:
useEffect(() => {
  document.title = `Count: ${count}`;
}, [count]);

docs.title: Custom Hooks
docs.text:
• What: Reusable logic shared across components.
  • Example:
function useToggle(initial = false) {
  const [value, setValue] = useState(initial);
  const toggle = () => setValue(v => !v);
  return [value, toggle];
}

docs.title: Batching
docs.text:
• What: React groups multiple state updates into one render cycle.
  • Example:
setX(1);
setY(2); // Both update together, not separately

docs.title: Re-render
docs.text: • What: Component function executes again due to changed state or props.

docs.title: Memoization
docs.text:
• What: Cache values or functions to avoid re-computation.
  • Example:
const result = useMemo(() => heavyCalculation(num), [num]);
const handleClick = useCallback(() => doSomething(), []);

docs.title: Lazy Loading
docs.text:
• What: Load components only when needed for performance.
  • Example:
const About = React.lazy(() => import('./About'));

docs.title: Unidirectional Data Flow
docs.text:
• What: Data flows parent → child (never backward).
  • Why: Makes data flow predictable.

docs.title: Prop Drilling
docs.text:
• What: Passing props through multiple layers unnecessarily.
  • Fix: Use context or state management.

docs.title: Context API
docs.text:
• What: Provides global data access without prop drilling.
  • Example:
const ThemeContext = createContext();
const value = useContext(ThemeContext);

docs.title: JSX
docs.text:
• What: JavaScript syntax extension combining HTML + JS.
  • Example:
const element = <h1>Hello React</h1>;

docs.title: Synthetic Events
docs.text:
• What: React’s cross-browser wrapper around native DOM events.
  • Example:
<button onClick={(e) => console.log(e.target)}>Click</button>

docs.title: Strict Mode
docs.text:
• What: Development-only tool to detect side effects and bad patterns.
  • Example:
<React.StrictMode>
  <App />
</React.StrictMode>

  • Lifting state, controlled inputs, and hooks are core patterns.
  • Reconciliation ensures minimal DOM updates.
  • Memoization, batching, and context improve performance and maintainability.

import React, { useState } from 'react';

function ProductList({ products }) {
  const [sortBy, setSortBy] = useState('name'); // Default sort by name

  const handleSortChange = (event) => {
    setSortBy(event.target.value);
  };

  const sortedProducts = [...products].sort((a, b) => {
    if (sortBy === 'price') {
      return a.price - b.price;
    } else {
      return a.name.localeCompare(b.name);
    }
  });

  return (
    <div>
      <select value={sortBy} onChange={handleSortChange}>
        <option value="name">Name</option>
        <option value="price">Price</option>
      </select>
      <ul>
        {sortedProducts.map(product => (
          <li key={product.id}>{product.name} - ${product.price}</li>
        ))}
      </ul>
    </div>
  );
}

export default ProductList;

import { FixedSizeList } from 'react-window';

const Row = ({ index, style }) => (

);

);

import React from 'react';
import { VariableSizeList } from 'react-window';

const getItemSize = index => {
  // Logic to determine the height of the item at the given index
  return 50 + (index % 3) * 20; // Example: Varying heights
};

const Row = ({ index, style }) => (
  <div style={style}>
    Row {index} - Height: {getItemSize(index)}px
  </div>
);

const ExampleVariableList = ({ itemCount }) => (
  <VariableSizeList

    width={400}
    itemCount={itemCount}
    itemSize={getItemSize} // Pass the function to calculate item size

docs.title: Using Immutable.js
docs.text:
import { List, Map } from 'immutable';

// Creating an immutable list
const myList = List([1, 2, 3]);

// Adding an item to the list (returns a new list)
const newList = myList.push(4);

console.log(myList.toJS()); // Output: [1, 2, 3] (original list is unchanged)
console.log(newList.toJS()); // Output: [1, 2, 3, 4] (new list with the added item)

// Creating an immutable map (object)
const myMap = Map({ name: 'John', age: 30 });

// Updating a value in the map (returns a new map)
const newMap = myMap.set('age', 31);

console.log(myMap.toJS()); // Output: { name: 'John', age: 30 } (original map is unchanged)
console.log(newMap.toJS()); // Output: { name: 'John', age: 31 } (new map with the updated value)

docs.title: Avoid Inline Functions in Render Methods
docs.text:
// Bad
const MyComponent = ({ items }) => {
  return (
    <ul>
      {items.map(item => (
        <li key={item.id} onClick={() => console.log(item.id)}>
          {item.name}
        </li>
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
};

// Good
const MyComponent = ({ items }) => {
  const handleClick = id => {
    console.log(id);
  };

  return (
    <ul>
      {items.map(item => (
        <li key={item.id} onClick={() => handleClick(item.id)}>
          {item.name}
        </li>
      ))}
    </ul>
  );
};

# Installation

Tailwind CSS can be installed in multiple ways depending on the tech stack.  
This guide breaks down installation via:

- CDN (quick prototyping)
- npm (recommended)
- Framework setups (Next.js, Vite, React, Vue, Angular)

---

# 🚀 1. Install Tailwind via CDN (Fastest for Prototyping)

Use this method **only** for quick experiments or CodePen-style demos.

```html
<script src="https://cdn.tailwindcss.com"></script>
```

Optional: Inline config

<script>
  tailwind.config = {
    theme: {
      extend: {
        colors: {
          primary: '#4f46e5',
        },
      },
    },
  };
</script>

⚠️ Not recommended for production. No PurgeCSS → huge CSS size. No custom configuration. No JIT mode.

docs.title: Step 1 — Create project
docs.text:
mkdir my-project
cd my-project
npm init -y

docs.title: Step 2 — Install Tailwind + PostCSS + Autoprefixer
docs.text: npm install tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer

docs.title: Step 3 — Create config files
docs.text:
npx tailwindcss init -p

This generates:

tailwind.config.js
postcss.config.js

docs.title: 📌 3. Add Tailwind to your CSS
docs.text:
Create src/input.css:

@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;

docs.title: 🔧 4. Configure Template Paths (Important)
docs.text:
In tailwind.config.js:

module.exports = {
  content: ['./src/**/*.{html,js}'],
  theme: {
    extend: {},
  },
  plugins: [],
};

⚠️ Catch Point: If content paths are wrong, Tailwind classes will not apply or will be missing after build.

docs.title: 🛠 5. Build CSS (Development Mode)
docs.text:
npx tailwindcss -i ./src/input.css -o ./dist/output.css --watch

Include in HTML:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="./dist/output.css" />

docs.title: 🟦 Next.js
docs.text:
npx create-next-app@latest my-app
cd my-app
npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
npx tailwindcss init -p

Content paths:

content: ['./pages/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}', './components/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}'];

Add Tailwind to globals.css.

docs.title: 🟨 Vite (React, Vue, Svelte)
docs.text:
npm create vite@latest my-app
cd my-app
npm install
npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
npx tailwindcss init -p

docs.title: 🟦 React (CRA)
docs.text:
npx create-react-app my-app
cd my-app
npm install -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer
npx tailwindcss init -p

Content paths:

content: ['./src/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}'];

docs.title: 🟧 Angular
docs.text:
ng new my-app
cd my-app
ng add @ngneat/tailwind

docs.title: 🎯 Summary
docs.text:
• CDN = quick prototype
  • npm = full power + customization
  • Frameworks require template paths
  • tailwind.config.js is core for extending themes

# PostCSS, PurgeCSS, and Tailwind JIT Explained

Tailwind relies on PostCSS for processing, and uses a purge-like mechanism to remove unused CSS.

---

# 🧩 What is PostCSS?

A CSS processor that handles tasks like:

- autoprefixing
- Tailwind processing
- minification

Your `postcss.config.js` will look like:

```js
module.exports = {
  plugins: {
    tailwindcss: {},
    autoprefixer: {},
  },
};

docs.title: 🧹 Purging Unused CSS
docs.text:
Before Tailwind v3, PurgeCSS was required. Now Tailwind uses content scanning + JIT engine, automatically removing unused classes.

⚠️ If classes do not appear in content paths → they are removed.

docs.title: ✨ JIT Mode (Now Always Enabled)
docs.text:
JIT compiles CSS on-demand and offers:

  • instant builds
  • arbitrary values (mt-[23px])
  • tiny production output

docs.title: 🧱 Safelisting (Must-Know)
docs.text:
Sometimes you generate dynamic class names in React/Vue, e.g.:

<div className={`bg-${status}-500`}></div>

Tailwind cannot detect these dynamic class names.

Solution:

safelist: [
  { pattern: /bg-(red|green|blue)-(500|600)/ }
],

docs.title: 🧪 Example: Production Build
docs.text: NODE_ENV=production npx tailwindcss -o dist/output.css --minify

docs.title: ⚠️ Common Pitfalls
docs.text:
• Class names constructed as strings will be purged.
  • Missing paths → utilities disappear.
  • Do not integrate old PurgeCSS plugins; Tailwind already handles purging.

```md
# Setup Pitfalls

Tailwind is powerful — but beginners often face setup issues.
Here are the most common ones and how to fix them.

---

# ❌ 1. Wrong Content Paths

Problem:

```js
content: ["./src/*.html"]

This excludes nested folders → Tailwind purges everything.

Correct:

content: ['./src/**/*.{html,js,jsx,ts,tsx,vue}'];

docs.title: ❌ 2. CSS File Not Included
docs.text:
Make sure this file exists and is imported:

@tailwind base;
@tailwind components;
@tailwind utilities;

Common mistake:

<link href="input.css" />

Should be:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="./dist/output.css" />

docs.title: ❌ 3. Missing PostCSS Plugins
docs.text: postcss.config.js must include tailwindcss and autoprefixer.

docs.title: ❌ 4. Using Tailwind CDN in Production
docs.text:
This produces:

  • Large bundle sizes
  • No purging
  • No custom config

docs.title: ❌ 5. Dynamic Class Names Not Detected
docs.text:
Example:

<div className={`bg-${color}-500`}></div>

Fix:

safelist: [/bg-(red|blue|green)-(500|600)/];

docs.title: ❌ 6. Tailwind Not Rebuilding (Watch Not Working)
docs.text:
Caused by:

  • Wrong paths
  • Wrong -i and -o
  • File inside ignored directory

docs.title: ❌ 7. Overusing @apply
docs.text:
Bad:

.btn {
  @apply px-4 py-2 bg-blue-500 text-white font-bold rounded shadow;
}

⚠️ This recreates Bootstrap-style CSS → defeats utility-first purpose.

Only apply layout-level patterns.

docs.title: 🎯 Summary
docs.text:
• Correct paths are essential
  • Avoid dynamic string class names
  • Do not abuse @apply
  • Ensure proper PostCSS setup

docs.title: Comparison: Tailwind CSS vs Traditional CSS Frameworks
docs.text:
Traditional CSS frameworks like Bootstrap, Bulma, or Foundation rely on pre-built components, while Tailwind provides utility classes to build custom components.

Below is an in-depth comparison.

docs.title: 🔍 1. Design Freedom
docs.text:
Feature Tailwind CSS Bootstrap / Others Custom Designs ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ ⭐⭐ Predefined Components ⭐ ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Customization Effort Medium High

Tailwind gives you complete flexibility to craft any UI.

docs.title: 🔍 2. File Size & Optimization
docs.text:
Tailwind uses JIT (Just-In-Time mode) and purge optimization, enabling tiny final CSS bundles (often < 10 KB).

Bootstrap ships with a large static file (150–200 KB).

docs.title: 🔍 3. Learning Curve
docs.text: Factor Tailwind Bootstrap Initial Learning Medium Easy Deep Customization Easy Hard Scalability Excellent Limited

docs.title: 🔍 4. Maintainability
docs.text:
Utility classes prevent:

  • Naming conflicts
  • CSS overrides
  • Large unused CSS files

Tailwind encourages small, predictable styles.

docs.title: 📍 Bootstrap
docs.text:
<div class="card">
  <div class="card-body">Hello World</div>
</div>

### 📍 Tailwind ```html
<div class="p-4 shadow rounded bg-white">Hello World</div>

Much simpler and more customizable.

---

## 🧠 Summary

| Criteria               | Winner             |
| ---------------------- | ------------------ |
| Customization          | **Tailwind**       |
| Speed to prototype     | **Bootstrap**      |
| Long-term scalability  | **Tailwind**       |
| File size optimization | **Tailwind (JIT)** |
| Prebuilt components    | **Bootstrap**      |

**Tailwind CSS** is the better choice for scalable, modern, component-based UI development.

docs.title: What is Tailwind CSS?
docs.text:
Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that provides low-level utility classes like p-4, text-center, bg-blue-500, flex, and grid — enabling developers to build custom designs without writing traditional CSS.

Unlike component-based frameworks (like Bootstrap), Tailwind gives you complete control over your design, letting you construct unique UI elements with small, composable classes.

docs.title: 🔹 Utility-First Approach
docs.text: Tailwind offers hundreds of extremely granular classes that do one thing well — such as margin, padding, color, alignment, and layout.

docs.title: 🔹 Design Freedom
docs.text: There are no predefined components that limit your creativity.

docs.title: 🔹 Fully Customizable
docs.text:
The tailwind.config.js file allows you to override:

  • Colors
  • Spacing scale
  • Breakpoints
  • Fonts
  • Shadows
  • Themes

docs.title: 🔹 Developer Productivity
docs.text: With auto-completion (via Tailwind IntelliSense) and class-based styling, it accelerates the UI building process.

docs.title: 🧩 Example
docs.text:
<button class="px-4 py-2 bg-blue-600 text-white rounded hover:bg-blue-700">
  Save
</button>

No external CSS file required — everything is done through utility classes.

docs.title: 🎯 Summary
docs.text:
Tailwind CSS is ideal for developers who want:

  • Full design control
  • Cleaner, component-driven CSS
  • Fast prototyping
  • Highly maintainable styling systems

It balances flexibility with consistency — making it one of the most widely adopted CSS frameworks today.

docs.title: Why Use Utility-First CSS?
docs.text: Utility-first CSS is a modern styling approach that uses small, single-purpose classes (e.g., mx-auto, flex, text-lg, bg-gray-200) to build UIs.

docs.title: 🔹 1. Faster Development
docs.text: Since you avoid switching between HTML and CSS files, styling is much quicker.

docs.title: 🔹 2. Zero Naming Conflicts
docs.text: Stop worrying about CSS class naming like BEM, OOCSS, SMACSS, etc.

docs.title: 🔹 3. Consistency Across UI
docs.text:
Tailwind's predefined scales ensure consistent:

  • Spacing
  • Colors
  • Shadows
  • Fonts

docs.title: 🔹 4. Highly Maintainable
docs.text:
When each style is defined through utilities, debugging becomes much easier.

Catch Point: You don’t need to search through CSS files to find where something is overridden — the styles are visible right in the markup.

docs.title: 📌 Traditional CSS
docs.text:
<button class="primary-btn">Save</button>

```css .primary-btn { padding: 12px 16px; background: #1d4ed8; color: #fff;
border-radius: 6px; } .primary-btn:hover { background: #1e40af; }

### 📌 Utility-First Equivalent

```html
<button class="px-4 py-3 bg-blue-600 text-white rounded-md hover:bg-blue-700">
  Save
</button>
```

Cleaner. Faster. No context switching.

---

## 🧠 When Utility-First Shines

- Component-heavy apps (Dashboards, SaaS UI).
- Design systems needing consistency.
- Teams who iterate UI frequently.
- Projects that prioritize speed.

Utility-first styling is not only efficient but also developer-friendly — and Tailwind is the best implementation of this philosophy.
